awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 International Conference on Computer-Aided Verification (CAV)
awd_abstract_narration:
This travel grant provides support for 15 US-based students to attend the 30th Conference on Computer-Aided Verification (CAV) to be held in New York City, July 15-18th 2019. CAV, one of the premier conference in formal verification, is dedicated to the advancement of the theory and practice of computer-aided formal analysis and synthesis methods for hardware and software systems. The conference covers the spectrum from theoretical results to concrete applications, with an emphasis on practical verification tools and the algorithms and techniques that are needed for their implementation. 

This travel grant will enable career development and learning opportunities for US-based and/or US citizen graduate students. Attending conferences like CAV is an important component of graduate school education for our society's future computer science researchers. Students have the opportunity to discuss leading edge research with world-class researchers in formal methods, and establish networks, connections, and mentoring relationships that will serve them well during their research careers.  This project aims at increasing the participation of students from underrepresented groups and those from smaller institutions of education, to provide them with equal opportunities, rather than leave them behind.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Conferences like Computer-Aided Verification (CAV) are a near-unique opportunity for students to get together with the very leaders of the field, hear their presentations, tell them their own story, receive their feedback. Hence, encouraging attendance at conferences is critical for promoting the development of students, particularly those who otherwise may not have the means to travel to conferences, for example because they lack a publication, or because the cost of traveling is too high.

CAV is the premier international conference and principal publication venue for research on computer-aided verification. It provides a forum for a broad range of advanced research in areas ranging from model checking and automated theorem proving to testing, synthesis and related fields. Research reported in CAV includes the application of formal methods to many kinds of systems, including hardware, software and communication protocols. It covers many system models, including finite state and infinite state systems, hybrid systems and probabilistic systems. It encompasses both theory and industrial case studies. The common thread is the use of automation to help designers build more reliable systems.

This travel grant supported the travel of 15 US-based students to attend CAV 2019 in New York, NY. The grant covered travel costs, the conference fee, and shared accommodation. A detailed report, including testimonial how the provided funding helped the awardees with their research and career development, is available as part of the final project report.

Society has been impacted by this project via the upbringing of a better prepared and better educated generation of future verification scientists and engineers. These are the people who will ensure the safety of our future computing systems, including self-driving cars, medical devices, and communication infrastructure.
